titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the John H. Knowles Papers FA047

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-05-18 00:51:34 -0400.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted are noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The John H. Knowles papers are divided into six series:
Original order has been maintained as far as possible.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Physician, medical administrator, author, and president of The Rockefeller Foundation. John Hilton Knowles was born May 23, 1926, in Chicago, Illinois, the son of James and Jean Trumbull Knowles. Dr. Knowles received his A.B. from Harvard College (1947) and his M.D. from Washington University School of Medicine (1951). On June 13, 1953, he married Edith M. LaCroix; they had six children.

Dr. Knowles began his medical career in 1951 when he was appointed intern at Massachusetts General Hospital. From 1953-1955 he served as Officer-in-Charge of the Cardiopulmonary Laboratory at Portsmouth Naval Hospital in Portsmouth, Virginia. He returned to Massachusetts General Hospital as a resident, specializing in diseases of the heart and lungs, leaving a year later to do postdoctoral work with the United States Public Health Service at the Universities of Rochester and Buffalo. In 1958 he became Chief Resident in Internal Medicine at Massachusetts General Hospital. The following year he was named Chief of the Pulmonary Disease Unit.

In 1962, Dr. Knowles was appointed General Director of Massachusetts General Hospital, the youngest director in the hospital's history. During the next ten years he upgraded working conditions and wages of the hospital staff, established a medical station at Logan International Airport that was connected to the hospital via television, approved the creation of nine intensive-care units including one for the diagnosis and care of cancer patients, and won better rates for hospitals from Blue Cross. He developed a strong interest in social issues of medicine and supported comprehensive federal health insurance and advocated preventive medicine. He was one of a team of doctors sent to Vietnam by President Johnson in 1967 to review and make recommendations concerning the health of the civilian population. In 1969 President Nixon nominated him for the post of Assistant Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare. The nomination was withdrawn six months later because of violent conservative opposition led by Senator Everett Dirkson and the American Medical Association. Prior to leaving Massachusetts General Hospital, Dr. Knowles was censured by the Massachusetts Medical Society for writing an article asserting that many physicians charged exorbitant fees and performed unnecessary operations.

Dr. Knowles left Massachusetts General Hospital in December 1971 and assumed the presidency of The Rockefeller Foundation in July 1972. Among his activities as Foundation president, he established an international relations program to focus on common global problems and set up the Foundation's publishing division to distribute reports on various Foundation-funded conferences. Dr. Knowles also remained active in the field of medicine; New York University Medical Center appointed him professor of medicine. He was a member of Nelson A. Rockefeller's Commission for Critical Choices (1974), editing the commission's final report "Doing Better and Feeling Worse." In 1975 he visited China with the National Committee on United States-China Relations, Inc., a group of "key United States leaders of world affairs," for a first-hand experience of China.
Dr. Knowles died of cancer on March 6, 1979.

A prolific writer and speaker, Dr. Knowles had over 60 articles and 4 books to his credit, including "Vietnam: Medicine and Politics," "Doing Better and Feeling Worse," and "Respiratory Physiology and its Clinical Application," a textbook still used by medical students. He also left two incomplete manuscripts: "Dr. Knowles' Journal" describing the HEW appointment controversy, and "Essays on Medicine and Health."
For a full list of activities, organizations, and honors, see "Who's Who in America," 40th edition, volume 1, 1978-1979, p. 1812, and the RAC biography file.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The John H. Knowles papers consist of professional and personal correspondence, reports, manuscripts, scrapbooks, appointment calendars, information files, photographs, slides, tapes, and a film relating to his administrative posts at Massachusetts General Hospital and The Rockefeller Foundation, and to his medical career. Most of the papers date from his tenure at Massachusetts General Hospital. There is very little concerning The Rockefeller Foundation or his personal life.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Edith L. Knowles donated the papers of John H. Knowles to the Rockefeller Archive Center in 1980.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence, class notes, research notes, and manuscripts relating to Knowles's undergraduate and graduate training, and to his research in diseases of the heart and lungs at Portsmouth Naval Hospital, as a United States Public Health Service fellow, and as intern and resident at Massachusetts General Hospital.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged by subject and chronologically within each subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series 2 contains papers documenting Knowles's professional and personal activities during his tenure at Massachusetts General Hospital, 1959-1971.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is divided into 6 subseries:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Subseries A concerns Knowles's career at Massachusetts General Hospital, first as chief of the Pulmonary Unit and later as General Director. Types of material in this subseries include correspondence, reports, minutes, and newsletters. Subjects include staff appointments, committee meetings, administrative philosophy, MGH fellows, and the MGH medical unit at Logan Airport.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged alphabetically by subject, and chronologically within each subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Subseries B documents Knowles's professional interests and activities, through correspondence, reports, and lecture notes. Subjects include speaking engagements, congressional testimony on medical costs and government health insurance, the 1967 trip to Vietnam, the 1969 proposed appointment as assistant secretary of the Department of Health, Education, and Welfare, chapters for Harrison's Textbook of medicine, teaching lectures at Harvard, regional planning, and work with Boston City Hospital, McLean Hospital, and various New York City hospitals.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged alphabetically by subject, and chronologically within each subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Subseries E consists of one folder of articles about Dr. Knowles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Subseries F contains the information files Dr. Knowles kept for reference purposes. Subjects include health insurance, medical education, nursing, mental health, and social problems.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged alphabetically by topic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence relating to Knowles's appointment as president of The Rockefeller Foundation, covering the time between his resignation from Massachusetts General Hospital (December 1971) and the time he officially assumed presidency of the Foundation (July 1972). Included are letters from the Foundation's outgoing president George Harrar, congratulatory letters, and professional and personal correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of papers documenting Knowles's activities while president of The Rockefeller Foundation.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is divided into 6 subseries:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Subseries A consists of correspondence, reports, and clippings relating to Knowles's work as president of The Rockefeller Foundation. Subjects include itineraries; trips to Cali, Colombia, St. Lucia, and Africa; trustee meetings; testimony before the House Subcommittee on Health and the Environment; and speeches by John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged alphabetically by subject and chronologically within each subject.

did.unittitle: Committee on Critical Choices for America

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Subseries B documents Knowles's professional interests and activities, mainly in the field of medicine. Subjects include the book "Doing Better and Feeling Worse," speaking engagements, the report "China Diary" of his 1975 trip to China, the Institute of Medicine, and an interview by the Kennedy Oral History Program.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged alphabetically by subject and chronologically within each subject. There is also a correspondence file (1972-1975) arranged alphabetically by correspondent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Subseries C contains biographical material and correspondence relating to Dr. Knowles's personal interests, including clubs and finances. It also includes get-well correspondence to Dr. Knowles during his illness and sympathy letters to Mrs. Knowles after his death.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged alphabetically by subject and chronologically within each subject.

scopecontent.p: Subseries F consists of one folder of information files that Dr. Knowles kept for reference purposes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains odd sized items, including weekly appointment cards (1961-1970), appointment calendars (1959-1979), 21 scrapbooks (1962-1972) containing clippings, photographs, letters, and memorabilia; miscellaneous newspaper clippings, certificates and plaques, microscope slides and lantern slides, reel and cassette tapes, and three watercolors of Dr. Knowles and an aerial view of Boston.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Materials requiring specialized equipment for access (audio tape, film) may be closed to research dependent on availability of the applicable equipment.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Brittle or damaged items, or materials otherwise in need of preservation care, may be closed to researchers at the discretion of the RAC Head of Archival Services / Head of Reference.
